results.title: What is art? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art in Action”.
A parade of the five elements of art: colour, light and dark, line, texture to encourage search for new relationships, experimentation with materials and understanding of these elements in terms of art.

results.title: What is an original print?
results.creator_credit: Oxide City Productions and RATAS Arts Consultancy
results.brief_description: A guide to the processes and techniques of original printmaking. Demonstrates relief prints (woodcuts, linocuts), incised or intaglio prints (engravings, etchings), lithography and serigraphy (silkscreen). Presented by Josef Lebovic.

results.title: What is a map?
results.brief_description: A small girl, writing to her friend, attempts to explain what her bedroom looks like. By use of animation and photographic techniques, the concept of maps is introduced and explained, first in terms of the living room plan and then in terms of a map of the neighbourhood.

results.title: What is a limit? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: David Nelson, Edward Goldwyn and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Analysis is that branch of mathematics which gives precision to vague terms like ‘infinitely large’ and ‘infinitesimally small’ and is founded on the concept of a limit. In this program, ideas behind a limit are examined and a formal definition to the limit of a sequence is reached.

results.title: What is a computer? (NP)
results.creator_credit: Robert Reid, International Computers and Video Arts
results.brief_description: This film gives an introduction to the computer. Explains the relationship between the central processing unit and the computer’s peripherals - the video console, the printer, the card reader, the magnetic tape unit and the disc unit. Narrated by John Cleese. Also suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: What is a computer?
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hayward, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Uses animation to dispel some of the mysteries about computers, while systematically presenting the basic ideas about computer operations. Explains storage of information, processing of input data, and printing out of responses. Demonstrates use of a flow chart and the diagram logic circuits of the AND, NOT and OR relations. An excellent and interesting explanation for beginners. Writen by Stan Hayward.

results.title: What if your town....?
results.creator_credit: Barry Pierce and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This film shows how to set up a “mutual aid” plan, which is a system of self-help whereby members of an industrial estate can pool their disaster and fire fighting resources for their mutual benefit.

results.title: What do you know?: screen quiz No. 1
results.brief_description: A humorous film in a slightly slapstick style of a trivia quiz show. Asks such questions as: What is the weight of a dry Australian rules football? Where are a crab’s teeth found? Can a horse sleep standing up? etc. Relevent shots are shown relating to each question and choice answers are provided with a counting down clock. Includes footage of Melbourne, including Swanston and Collins Streets, and a game of Australian Rules football (Carlton vs Collingwood?). Interesting film from an historic point of view. Photography by David J. Bilcock. Written and narrated by Norman Ellis.

results.title: What do girls want from boys?
results.brief_description: An open ended film from the “Searching years” series in which a group of young people discuss the problems of dating at high school level and the needs of girls in a close relationship. Why do girls often prefer to date older boys? What does a girl mean when a ask to be “treated like a woman?”
